title: New mum has her licence suspended after her GP warned her not to get behind the wheel
text:
A mother had her license suspended for driving one week after she had a cesarean section, after her doctor warned her against getting behind the wheel.

The first-time single mum prematurely gave birth in Newcastle on September 6 and was on the road to recovery when she asked her GP to give her a certificate allowing her to drive.

The doctor refused to give permission to the 42-year-old woman, despite the fact she was no longer taking pain medication.

The GP told the mother, who wished to remain anonymous, that she would tell Roads and Maritime Services that she wasn't medically fit to drive and defied medical advice, the Sydney Morning Herald reported.

A mother had her license suspended for driving one week after she had a cesarean section, after her doctor warned her against getting behind the wheel

The doctor referred to the Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists guidelines which recommends mothers don't drive for two to six weeks after having a c-section.

A few days later the RMS suspended the mother's license, which meant she wasn't able to drive the eight kilometers to see her son in the neonatal intensive care unit of John Hunter Hospital.

'It was incredibly distressing to think that my baby could need me and my one means of getting to him was taken away from me,' the mother said.

'If something happened in the middle of the night I would have had to wait for someone to drive me to the hospital.'

The woman said the situation was traumatising because just three months earlier she was incorrectly pulled over and arrested over a kidnapping she had nothing to do with after her number plate was stolen.

RANZCOG guidelines state that women 'need to be able to sit comfortably, work the controls, wear a seat belt, look over their shoulder, make an emergency stop, and should not be using any medication or analgesics that cause sedation.'

The mother said she went through the checklist of recommendations before she got started driving.

College president Vijay Roach said that in general, women who have undergone an uncomplicated c-section are able to drive safely after a week or two.

'Rather than rely on the fact that a woman has recently had a caesarean, we would recommend doctors assess her overall physical ability to drive based on a full evaluation,' Dr Roach said.

The mother is now allowed back behind the wheel after Transport for NSW removed the suspension.

Her license was reinstated after she contacted Minister for Transport and Roads Andrew Constance, and submitted a report from the head of obstetrics at John Hunter Hospital who said she was medically fit to drive.

authors: Alana Mazzoni For Daily Mail Australia
